Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History Collections: Transfer, Renovation, and Integration of the Otolith Collection of the Alaska Fisheries Science Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to (1) enrich and enhance the Fish Collection of the University of Washington (UW), (2) secure and improve a unique and irreplaceable biological resource, and (3) resolve a critical hazardous materials issue by relocating, curating, and integrating a huge and diverse collection of fish otoliths (which have enormous realized and unknown potential value) built over the past 40 years by NOAA Fisheries personnel at the Alaska Fisheries Science Center (AFSC).

In addition to resolving an urgent hazardous-materials issue, educational opportunities for student training in collection management will be offered to graduate students as well as undergraduates. Otolith biology is already a part of the lab portion of the PI's 300-level "Biology of Fishes," which attracts about 130 undergraduates annually but, to further undergraduate participation, the PI will serve as UW sponsor for two, 10-week, "otolith" internships as part of AFSC's long-standing summer internship program. Aspects of the project will also be added to our well-established and ever-popular program of public outreach, which provides educational opportunities to an average of about 550 visitors to the Fish Collection annually. Project personnel will also work closely with AFSC personnel in assisting with their on-going contributions to education by way of the annual NOAA Science Camp for local high schools, Seattle Science Center research exhibits, and Seattle Aquarium events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds provided by the NSF have saved a huge and priceless collection (2.4 million pairs) of otoliths (small bony structures in the inner ear of fishes that function in hearing and balance) collected by NOAA personnel over the past 40 years from California to Alaska, Aleutian Islands, Bering Sea, and the Arctic Ocean. The collection, representing nearly 100 species and now part of the UW Fish Collection was previously stored in alcohol-filled glass vials, arranged in Styrofoam boxes, and stacked on pallets scattered randomly throughout a huge pre-WW II airplane hangar. The collection was poorly housed, disorganized, and badly underutilized. At the same time, housed in unimproved space, without sprinkler-protection, the collection constituted a significant safety and environmental compliance issue, in flagrant violation of Seattle City Fire Code. To eliminate this problem and to make the collection available to the scientific community, we (1) transferred the entire collection to the UW campus; (2) replaced the existing Styrofoam boxes with acid-free cardboard boxes; (3) sorted and rearranged the boxes on mobilized shelving in fire-safe, dedicated space; (4) curated and cataloged the entire collection; (5) made the collection available via an on-line search interface; and (6) featured the collection in our public outreach program. For a videographic overview of the project, see www.youtube.com/watch?v=xqI9SY1gl2Q

The importance of fish otoliths to a wide range of studies in biology is well documented. Otolith research continues to make substantial contributions to traditional fisheries management and stock assessment efforts while expanding its role in ecological research and conservation applications. Certain intrinsic properties of otoliths, including species-specific morphology, continual growth, deposition of distinct daily and seasonal increments, and ability to permanently record chemical aspects of the environment, combine to create one of the most versatile vertebrate structures available for use in scientific research and environmental management. Historically used for species identification and for age-and-growth estimation, as well as in understanding marine food-web structure, otoliths are now being used as biological tracers to address an astonishing array of new and different applications and research directions. Otolith research has made major contributions to our understanding of population structure, feeding ecology, early life history of fishes, migratory patterns, and ecosystem-based management.

Just as important as the otoliths themselves is the extraordinary amount of physical and biological information that goes along with each sample. To begin with, otoliths have complex external shapes that are species specific. For each pair of otoliths in the UW collection, precise data are available describing the specimen from which the otoliths originated: species, sex, length, weight, and, for about 40% of the samples, age. Also for each sample: geographic locality, date of capture, time of trawl start and finish, depth of capture, depth of gear, depth of the bottom, water temperate, and gear type. The collection thus represents a goldmine of information that can be used to address a whole host of questions related to biological and environmental issues.

The activities and results of this project have supported the UW's mission of research, education, and public service in making new and badly needed biological resources available to a broad constituency around the world. In addition to providing new and previously unavailable materials for the ichthyological community, the transfer of the otolith collection will benefit a host of other user groups in relatively unrelated fields, including geochemistry, oceanography, archeology, paleontology, anthropology, climatology, to name only a few.
